nobility alone ſo properly called onely vertue according trueſt opinion nobilitas ſola est atque vnica virtu title noble doth appertaine iuſtly hath walked • n pathes vertue making himſelfe famous owne induſtry according • remarkeable tract amorous poet nam genus proauos quae non fecimus ipſi vix ea noſtra voco yet notwithſtanding ſuch caſe vſe cuſtome hath ſo much preuailed • ow call nobleman iſſued deſcended father grandfather one two forenamed meanes elſe together howbeitmore honour man firſt laſt race • much honorable one thoſe mean rather firſt laſt race orator anſwered nobleman extraction yeoman plebeyans depraued liues one called gentleman • irſt tappe whoſe lance ſtood hayſtack meere contempt ego caeteris mei maioribus virtute mea praluxi ordinarily commeth ſo paſſe bramble queene hyſope commandeth cedar libanus scripture informeth v much ſay • hat degree nobility laſt go firſt deſcendunt statua vertue alone diſtinguiſheth men one anothervertue onely maketh men inuention would maske co • r face great leaues bardane rootes whereof beare burredockes • nd hearbe hurtfull labour virgill ſpeaketh firſt booke geor • cks lapaeque tribulique reaſon becauſe herbe called lapa ſurname perſonata accor •• ng teſtimony plinie mathiolus iudgement dioſcorides time firſt warres marched battaile elſe returned • cke victorie ſhaddowed cabaſſets murrians broad leaues • haec agendo virtutum triumpho glorioſus iuſtitiaeque c • lt • egregius cum mundi saluatore ſine fine merearis ad coeleſtia gaudia peruenire qui c • patre spiritusancto viuit regnat deus per omnia ſacula ſaeculorum amen receiue thy sword coupled ioyned god bleſſing wherewith vertue holyghoſt thou ſhalt preuaile reſiſt ouerthrow thine enemy aduerſaries holy church alſo protect armie god vnconquerable aſſiſtance triumpher ieſus chriſt lord guird thy sword vpon thy ſtrong thigh thou maiſt exerciſe power equity deſtroy ouerthrow hope iniquity god church faithfull people thereto belonging fight valiantly defend leſſe againſt falſe faith name chriſtians repell hoſtes ſuch enemy deſtroy widdowes orphanes clemently aſſiſt defend reſtore deſolate preſeruing deliuered thou ſhalt reuenge wronged confirme well diſpoſed performing theſe thing vertue hereof triumph gloriouſly worthy patron iuſtice world redeemer sauiour attaine heauenly ioyes without ending father holyghoſt liueth reigneth god world without end amen antiphona confortare eſto vir obſerua cuſtodias domini tui vt ambules vijs eius cuſtodias cerimonias eius praecepta eius teſtimonia iudicia quocunque te verteris confirmet te deus antiphonall good courage goe forth like man obſerue ordenances lord thou maiſt walke wayes keepe commandements precept teſtimonies iudgements way ſoeuer thou turneſt thee lord thee oremus deus qui prouidentia tua coelestia ſimul terrena moderaris propitiare famulo tuo n militiae tuae ſacris addicto vt omnis hoſtium ſuorum fortitudo virtute gladij spiritualis frangatur ac te pro illo pugnante penitus conteratur per dominum nostrum ieſum chriſtum c let v pray god gouerneth heauen earth thy prouidence bleſſe proſper thy ſeruant n vndertaking thy ſacred warfare hoſtes fortie pſalme beginning eructauit cor meum verbum bonum eight verſe whereof repeated three ſeuerall time concerning oath knight make receiuing order knighthood time place hath bin continually vniforme guardian holy sepulcher lord ieruſalemknights sepulcher conferring order holy sepulcher voyager comming ſo farre requeſting haue petrus bleſſenſis writeth nintie fourth epiſtle time knight went cuirie apre ly ly roi veſtie cotte armer de boban ly donna leſcu et ly hiaume de conuoitiſe ou il ot mainte pierre aſsiſe saphis rubis camahiez ly roys renart appellez et puis ſj ly commendez noblon apprehenderet ancient romancers called long knife warre miſerecorde mercythe knife called knife mercy becauſe ſuch souldiers knight beaten downe vanquiſhed beholding enemy graſpe knife hand ouer ready ſtab ſight helmet ſhirt coat male wanting haubert cried mercy deſiring life noble romant roſe ſaith thou manhood art good inclind take pittie let mercy rule thy minde thou diſcouereſt bleeding ſighes teares inſtead sword word frightfull feares mercy moſt maieſty appeares vndoubtedly author trueth rehearſe rudeſt ſtones diamond pierce let warres knife painted nere ſo faire yet point edge piercing men made profeſſion armes vſed weare swordsafter mā ner wearing dudgeon dagger thoſe kniues warre ſome others well citizen countryman weare girdle thoſe kniues warre yet behinde backes hanging downe thigh like baionets gaſcoigne young lad vſed weare euen childhood thoſe lad paris alſo elſewhere called bachelers much ſay ready yeares eſquires souldiers young maiden likewiſe apt mariage tearmed contained vnder name nori • um alpes norica inhabitant noriques called titus liutus bourbonnois theſe ex • ended rhine ſo farre paſſage citie trent maketh • ſeperation germanie land belonging state venice • hence ſo farre hungaria caeſar firſt booke gaules warres ſpeaking bourbonnois writeth heluetians swizzers tooke companion aſſociates boios qui trans rhenum incoluerant agrum noricum tranſie • ant norciamque oppugnarant receptes ad ſe ſocios ſibi adſciſcerant ſhew auncient dwelling gaules allemaigne germanie hungaria perticularly peopled berruyers concerning peopling hungaria morauia gaue • ame auaria changed afterward hungaria people called auares populi ſoone hunnes hungars peopled alſo morauia • name afterward pannoniaes much ſay lower • hungaria named auaria haue ſaid honored title kingdome higher archduchie auſtria named marche auſtria • harlemaigne conquered auen • ine writeth fourth booke hiſtory bauaria large theſe troupe colony gaules germanie caeſar ſpeaketh • xt booke bello gallico theſe word worthy remarked ac fuit ante tempus • um galli germanos virtute ſuperarent vltro bella inferrant ac propter hominum multitu • inem agrique inopiam trans rhenum colonias mitterent strabo ſaith much • ourth ſeauenth bookes geographie learned tacitus germania deducing briefely caeſar ſet • owne larger manner ſaith validiores olim gallorum re fuiſse▪ ſummus auctorum diuus • lius tradit eoque credibile eſt etiam gallos germaniam tranſgreſſos igitur inter hercy • ſyluam rhenumque moenum amnes heluetij vlteriora boij gallica vtraque gen • uere manet adhuc boiemi warre loſing longer patience enemy became friend making peace alliance yeare ſecond conſulſhip grace three hundred forty two hee choſe good number moſt valiant among wherewith hee filled romane legion head againſt emperor conſtantius proclaimed caeſar nephew iulian ſurnamed apoſtata ſent command ouer gaules wee haue already ſaid yeere grace three hundred fiftie ſixecullen recovered french time apoſtata aſſiſted potent armie recouered french city cologne made peace honor empire king france ſought compaſſe ambaſſadors ſo ſaith panegyriſt ammianus marcellinus 27 booke yeere following three hundred fifty ſeuen french perceiuing apoſtata gone vp farre warre againſt alemanesanother aduenture french detrimēt robbed thoſe townes vpon rhine made rode forth gaule get firſt ſhold come fingring apoſtata returning victory alemanes came fierce hot aſſault vpon theſe bootehalers whereof hee hewed great number peeces beſieged others 3 moneths together caſtle whereof got poſſeſſion meuze driuen flye intended intrap therefore purpoſely left thoſe cottage townes forſaken withdrawing themſelues thick • ſt part wood great wayes paſſages whereof bound faſt ſpreading branch tree knitting intricately ſtrong knot • one within another ſilly reuenge • ken romanesthe rom • n • fond fooliſh reuenge ſet village cottage fire onely meere deſpight becauſe found victualls ſigne trophy triumphes meanes free themſelues combined branch yet met worſe fortune vulgar prouerbe isthe romanes v • nat • • pro • ion fell feauer diſeaſe farre greater danger iſſuing forth forreſt came wide open fieldes mariſhes entrance ſides french purpoſely hidden themſelues within wood onely draw romanes thoſe myery field trembling earth full bogges quagmire wherein romanes much peſtered appeared frenchman top tree ſerued ſo many exalted tower turret diſcouery enemy draw neere let flie dart arrowes embalmed venemous hearbs cuſtome frenche impoyſon dart arrowesthe french • ed po •• oned dart wh • rewith greatly annoyed roman noted salique law firſt paragraphe title de vulner • bus lead like vnto thicke darke clowd breaketh hayle ſtormie raine euen ſo chanced poore romanes rather much worſe ſuch arrowes fell vpon skinne pierced feſ • ered immediately died rauing violence poyſon meanes french knew beſt warrantable ground aſſembled great number engirting romane armie made moſt terrible ſlaughter firſt rankes horſe ingulfed bogges men horſes beaſts carried charge luggagethe miſerable perple • ity romanes ſo deepely ſwallowed myres • meanes ſerued drawing likewiſe reſt followed ſteps ſubiect like ſucceſſe foot souldiers agile light horſeback although bemudded ſoyled filth moiſt field yet ſome difficultie got thence eſcaped thoſe wood whence iſſued morning hiding themſelues among buſhes till night came hath neither ſhame feare ſo ſheltered fauour thereof beſt manner could deuiſe poſſible whole armie thus confuſed rankes diſorder ſaue themſelues need demanded french ſafetie well reuenged charboniere forreſt great good market enemy heraclius maiſter campe du regiment legion iouinians command armie remained dead ſuch ſaued themſelues dayes misfortune ſmall number heare auouched sulpitius alexander third booke hiſtorie fourth booke ſpeaketh death victor laſt yongeſt ſonne tyran • maximus time place ſted nannius quintinus ſubrogated two captaines named carietto surius three diſtinctions concerning germanie army encamped themſelues face face france vpon confines germanie muſt vnderſtood firſt germanie ſide rhine allemaigne beyond elb germanie afterward call • franconia ſaith afterward french intruded themſelues againe germanie doubtleſſe firſt brought away thence vnſpeakeable bootie arbogaſtes vnwilling endure theſe brauadoes nothing elſe griefe vanquiſhed sunne stand ſtill ſtood ſtill theſe word paulinus per idem tempus arbogaſtes come aduerſus gentem ſuam hoc eſt francorum bellum parauit atque pugnando non paruam multitudinem manu fudit cum reſiduis armie ſide vpon day emperour ſate throne beheld arbogaſtes paſsing whoſe boldneſſe vnreuerent behauiour longer able ſuffer went thruſt hand countermand whereby tooke charge dignity constable colonell stilico againſt nation enemy romaine empire weſt exalting themſelues foe maiſter honorius firſt voyage si • ilico againſt mutinous nation weſt according teſtimonie poet claudian noateth voyage theſe perticularities hunc tamen primis populos lenire feroces et rhenum pacare iubes volat ille citatis vectus equis nullaque latus ſlipante caterua aſpera nubiferas qua rhetia porrigit alpes pergit hoſtiles tanta eſt fiducia ripas incomitatus adit totum properare per amnem firſt voyage count stilico take knowledge enemy whoſe deſignes wiſely preuented alwayes behoueth valiant leader warre doe without attendant armiethe preſence stilico dreadfull enemy neuer walketh counted ſteps stilico preſence onely ſecured frontier rhine gaue alemans french king ſufficient breathing embrace peace thereby ſalue anew comming themſelues moue ſide rhine —segnique verenter oſtendiſſe mora tranſuecti lintribus amnem againe attonitos reges humili ceruicae videres ante ducem noſtrum flauam ſparſere sicambri caeſariem pauidoſque orantes murmure franci procubuere ſolo iuratur honorius abſens imploratque tuum ſupplex alemannia nomen diſciphering aleman people performed homage ſaith baſternae venere forth honorius foote stilico armie paſſed greece fight againſt oſtrogothes intelligence count ruffinus ſeiſed prouinces ſubiected romaine empire alſo intelligence ſame ruffinus two conſtables gaines eaſt stilico weſt conſtrained leaue buſineſſe without thing coſt life ruffinus vſurpe eaſterne empire formerly raiſed vnknowne people inhabiting vnder north climate mariſhes meotides pannonia claudian ſaith firſt booke iam gens iſtrum mouet scythiamque receptat auxilio traditque ſuas hoſtilibus armis relliquias mixtis deſcendit sarmata dacis et qui cornipedes pocula vulnerat audax maſſagetes patriumque bibens maetium alanus membraque qui ferro gaudet pinxiſſe gelonus ruffino collecta manus ruffinus ſlaine roman armie▪ neere gonſtantinoplebut ruffinus liued enioy theſe matchmaking honorius conſull fourth time eutychianus gouernour aff •• ce named gildonus cauſed himſelfe proclamed emperour reuolting honorius gildonus proclaimed himſelfe emperor forthwith ſent stilico againſt priſoner marcomir king french made warpriſoner ſo boldly followed troupe french compelled reſt pleade agreement deſire peace ſuch condition ſhould pleaſing vanquiſher stilico ordered victory command emperour honorius sonne lawe made peace impoſing tribute french knew good souldiours certaine number muſt taken among ſerue romaine army expreſſe charge liue thenceforward quietneſſe without making foradgings rhine frontier according claudian ſaith — cum forte decorus cum stilicone gener pacem implorantibus vltro germanis reſponſa dabat legeſque chaicis arduus ſlauis ſignabat iura sueuis tribuit leges obſide foedera ſancit indicto bellorum alios tranſcribit vſus militet vt noſtris detonſa sicambria ſignis two word expreſſeth alemans name sweues french sicambrians haue related already stilico hauing left good garriſons defending rhine frontier stilico leadeth marcomir priſoner receiued hoſtages tooke way millaine leading along marcomir king french ſent priſoner sienna italie ended • fe ſoone departed thence king sunno brother marcomir succeſſour would needes make head againe endeauouring recouer bro • taking way repriſall certaine townes roman sunno brother marcomir ſlaine french ſlaine french themſelues would keepe peace ſworne roman thereby made meanes recouery king end theſe two brother king liuely deſcribed claudians regia romanus diſquirit crimina carcer marcomirus sunnoque docent quorum alter etruſcum pertulit exilium quum ſe promitteret alter exulis vltorem iacuit mucrone ſuorum re auidi conſcire nouas odioque furentes pacis ingenio ſcelerumque cupidine fratres death french ſeauenteene yeares without king • eing gouerned duke onely ſecond voyage stilico alemagne french time • encreaſed tranquile without damage man might trauaile thorow • hem claudian ſaith rhine furious ſwarming armed • roupes become like vnhorned stagge — rhenumque minacem cornibus infractis adeo miteſcere cogis vt salius iam rura colat flexoſque sicambri falcem curuent gladios ſeemed vtterly forſaken action warre vndertake • ickle scith addicting themſelues husbandry firſt ſe • ond germany freely paſſed rhine flockes heards let • oe feede mountaines france alemagne — geminaſque viator cum videat ripas quae ſit romana requirat vt iam trans fluuium non indignante chaico paſcat belga pecus mediumque ingreſſa per albim gallica francorum monte armenta pererrent ſame poet epithalamium empreſſe marie wife emperour honorius daughter count stilico telleth thenceforward ſhe might walke thorow alemagne france without euill encounter — iam rhenus albis seruiet medios ibis regina sicambros empire weſt thus calme tranquile stilico neuet bin conſul choſen firſt day serculare yeare foure hundred aurelianus claudian ſecond panegyricke ſpoken ſaid stilico maketh rome ſpeake manner qui mihi germanos ſolus francoſque ſubegit cur nondum legitur faſtis becauſe ſought make weſterne empire peaceable condition —nullus boreae metus omnis auſtri os ſilet cecidit maurus germania ceſsit et ianum pax alta ligat te conſule peace long moleſted pactiſes faction ſame stilico make euch • rius sonne emperour played ſpoileking honorius stilico conſpireth againſt honorius lordfor hauing bin created conſull ſecond time anthemius yeare grace foure hundred fiue practiſed ſtrange nation namely gothes holding greece part thrace ſhould come thundring italie afterward vnder conduct king alaricus meane ſide alans scythian vandales burgongnons nation north prepared themſelues goe take ſhare gaules neuer part thence onely pleaſe stilico vandale nation alaricus king gothes inuadeth italy meanes stilico alaricus comming italie practiſe intelligence yeare foure hundred ſixe stilico might giue freer paſſage northerne nation leueied company guarded rhine frontier cauſed come italie claudian ſaith agmina quin etiam flauis obiecta sicambris quaeque domant cattos immanſuetoſque cheruſcos huc omnes vertere mina tutumque remotis excubijs rhenum ſolo terrore reliquit time alaricus tooke ſacked rome making himſelfe rich ſpoyles thereof armie ſurprizall happened ninth calends september yeare grace foure hundred ten var ••• alone conſull eaſt created emperour arcadius •• norius nothing weſt goarus reſpendialus king alemagne expected ſhould become siedge rome • two king alemagne goarus reſpendialus coueted paſſe rhine infeſt gaule army firſt ranked himſelfe ſide honorius stilico sonne eucherius conuinced fellonie treaſon ſlaine romaine armie yeare foure hundred eight king named reſpendialus conſtrained make retreat forſake frontier rhine death stilico son eucherius yeare foure hundred ten vandales would plant themſelues • gaule paſſing way forradged land french becauſe could winne paſſage elſe well beaten three foure encounter one king godegiſilus ſhine field twenty thouſand people periſhing edge sword french vandales bin quite foyled alanes came time greateſt neede brought ſuccour paſſed riuer rhine ſame company thus enſtructed hiſtorian right kiſſing hand onely liegeman lampridius obſerueth life emperor alexander sola quae de hoſtibus capta ſunt limitaneis ducibus atque militibus donauit ita vt haered •• eſſent ſi haeredes militarent nec vnquam ad priuatos peruenirent ad didit animalia ſeruos vt poſſent colere quod acceperant precopius firſt booke vandales warres writeth giſericus gone spaine affrica hauing conquered part thereof diuided betweene two ſonnes honoricus genſonius theodatus yongeſt ſonne deceaſed without child beſt land houſes cattell hauing taken vanquiſhed affricans hee made partage deuiſion captaines borne becauſe capable taking vp gadge batell beare banner march vnder command men ought obedient order nature alſo right diuine humane hath beene practiſed time among nation greateſt fame woman neuer command eumonius king sparta dying left kingdome sonne polydectes deceaſed alſo without heyres maſle liuing onely hee two daughter ſo right brother lycurgus came kingdome vnderſtood within widdow brother great childe deliuered ſonne named charilaus truly noble minde licurgus ſignifieth ioy people hee cauſed acknowledged king giuing gouernment regencie mother ſetting crowne vpon head empire romanes neuer held commanded woman ariſtotle genius nature ſecond book politiques ninth chapter telleth v ſome people valiant couragious gouerned commanded woman qui ſexum imperijs minime diſcerunt celtas non imperari mulieribus ſaith ſame ariſtotle elſwhere obſerue politicks alleadged 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 cannot otherwiſe happen ſuch politique gouernment wealth bleſſings fortune cannot requeſt wiſedome saint mathew mat 626 conſiderate lilia agri quomodo creſcunt non laborant 〈◊〉 ne • lillie french field cannot gathered stranger hand none prince bloud may haue power ouer salique law ſole foundation kingdome excludeth daughtersthe salique law ſole foundation kingdome conſequently ſtrange prince marry ſo lilia non laborant externorum principum dominatione ſpinne neuer fall diſtaues daughter onely ſeene child deſcendants make pretence ſhew thoſe men impertinencie haue written salique law meerely imaginarie aboue one ancient author hath made note thereofobiection • againſt salique beard king firſt ſecond third line wore long vntill king lewis yong ſeuenth name cauſed haire cut regard certaine admonition giuen petrus lombardus biſhop paris whoſe sepulture ſeene church marcellus paris long haire dangling downe ſo farre ſhoulders continued vntill time king francis firſt hauing beene hurt firebrand fell vpon head cauſed haire ſhorneking francis firſt head broken firebrād hee might ſooner bee cured ſuffered beard grow ſtill cut quite away lewis ſeuenths time according example king francis weare headhaire cut ſhort beard long commonly subiest doth conforme faſhions ſees prince worne returne wee clodian began reigne yeere grace foure hundred thirty reigne continued eighteene yeeres sigibertus ſaith clodius filius pharamond regis rex crinitus regnat ſuper franco annis decem octo ſecond yeere reigne hee conquered thoringe yeere foure hundred thirty one according ſame sigibert theſe tearmes clodius thoringiam inuadit diſpargo caſtello thoringorum aliquandiu habitauit died father pharamond began conqueſt life time eſtabliſhed dwelling caſtle diſpargo haue formerly ſaid yere 445 ſame author affirmeth concerning king clodion ſent ſpies diſcouer roman condition towne cambray immediately following croſſed great riuer rhine chaſed romanes frontires thereof ouerthrew ranged battell great diſcomfiture beſieged tooke cambray ſtrength afterward tournay croſſing forreſt charboniere ſo farre artois riuer somme clodius rex francorum miſsis explora • orible diſpargo caſtello vſque ad vrbem cameracum tranſijt rhenum potrito multo romanorum populo citra rhenum vſque ligerim fluuium habitantium carbonariam syluam ingreſſus vrbem tornacum obtinuit inde vſque ad vr • bem cameracum properauit vbi pauco tempore reſidens romanos ſi quos ibi inuenit pere • exinde ad somenam fluuium perueniens omnia occupauit romanes held extendure countreywhat ſpacious compaſſe country romās held frontier rhine ſo farre riuer loire aſſembled armie maine great body couering ſpaciouſneſſe ground hinder paſſage clodion driuen flight great ſlaughter gaue meanes poſſeſſe country charboniere forreſt comprehended tournay valentiennes monts cambray purſuing ſtill purpoſed point ſpacious field artois sidonius apollinaris reporteth paſſage precedent chapter — quo cloio patentes attrebatum terras peruaſerat went ſo farre riuer somme sigebert calleth somenam • mituting biſhop poictiers fortunatus fourth poem ſeuenth book ſpeaking riuers france iſara sara chares scaldis saba somena sura alſo called sum • na somena taking ſourſe neere fountaines leſcauld enlarging ſelfe ſwelling vermandois whence maketh paſſage quintines peronne amiens abbeville vallery beneath somme runneth falleth impetuouſly lap ocean sea bound clodions conqueſts according teſtimony gregorie tour ſecond booke ninth chapter hiſtory france informeth v clodion attempted conqueſts romanes enioyed forreſt charboniere iuſt riuer loire beyond gothes muſt vnderſtand vuiſigothes held gaule ſo farre pyrenean mountain thoſe people tainted falſe doctrin wicked arrius bourgongnors ſectators ſame hereſie domineered beyond riuer rh • ſne neere city lyon ſame hiſtorian sigebert others ſet downe clodion aduanced conqueſt vnto riuer somme although functius ſome french annaliſts haue written • ee made himſelfe maſter city maguntla amiens city • eretofore built riuer somme romane emperours antoninus debonnaire sonne aurelius called somona brina reg •• ſaid riuer appellation ſaid changed •••• ambianus ab ambitu fluminum beit howſoeuer moſt certaine ſaid clodion conquered cambreſes honorable conqueſts king clo • ion farre extended tourneſes • tois henaulte citie cologne ſurnamed romaine agripina whereof sonnes deſcendants poſſeſſion entitled themſelues king vnto reigne clouis firſt chriſtian king exterminated reuniting crowne france land poſſeſſed recorded gregory tour end ſecond booke hiſtorie france clodion hauing reigned twenty yeares eighteene according ſome writer dyed caſtle diſparch thuringe carried franquemburge franconia laid sepulcher anceſtors left three maſle child ragnachaire death clodion election meroueus regnauld adalberon ouer yong yeares conſerue conqueſt father maintaine power armes yong riſing monarchie french elected king firſt prince blood called meroueus neere kinſeman deceaſed king clodion becauſe ſonne richomer ſon ingomer brother marcomir father pharamond ſo conſequent couſine germaine clodion whoſe sonnes hee tutour saint gregorie tour affirmeth ſecond booke ninth chapter ſaid meroueus iſſued blood royall neere kinſeman ſaid king clodion sigibert ſmall purpoſe mine opinion maketh ſonne ſaying yeare foure hundred fortie eight meroueus filius clodij ſuper fran •• regnat annis decem à quo nimis vtili rege franci merouingi cognominati ſunt truth king held kingdome vnto pepin le bref authour king ſecond ligne called carlouingians deſcended father sonne ſaid meroueus therefore called ligne king meroueus merouingians chap viii king meroueus biſhop auuergne sidonius apolinaris panegyricke ſpoken emperour maiorian obſeruing miſerable condition gaules vpon declining romaine empire ſo many tyrant poſſeſſ •• themſelues gouernements title emperours haue declared ſuch confuſion knew certaine lord maket • poore romaine eagle ſpeake manner —mea gallia rerum ignoratur adhuc dominus ignoraque ſeruit ſhewing meanes french poſſeſſed themſelues thereof begi • ning conqueſt panegyricke emperour auitus father law ſaith francus germanum primum belgamque ſecundum sternebat enſtructing v began frontier rhine continued poſſeſſion belgicke gaule caeſar alloweth third part rich abounding gaules roman conqueſt • ſame caeſar parted deuided many gouernments narrow 〈◊〉 deuiſions concerning belgicke gaule deuided twainethe deuiſion belgicke gaule firſt ſecond belgicam primam belgicam ſecundam firſt within encloſures mediomatrices leucos viri dunenſes containdure firſt huius erat caput metropolis treueris mentz toul verdum towne citie treuers metropolitane ſecond vnder iuriſdiction sueſsiones catalaunos camaracos neruiot iuriſdictions ſecond morinos attrebates ambianos bellouacos nouiomagenſes quorum erat metropolis durocortorum remorum thoſe soiſſons ch • alons tournay terouence arras amiens beauuais noyon people ſtrong citie rheims capitall ſame belgicke gaule moreouer deuided ſame romaine firſt longer tournay terouenne raced warres king fraunces firſt emperour charles fift people dwelling ſhoares ocean sea capitall towne ſecond germanie citie cologne rhine may ſuffice vnderſtand paſſage nation north departed hungaria mightie armie conſiſted ſeauen fiue hundred thouſand men wherewith • auaged treuers strasbourg eaſter eauen entred ſtoutly citie mentz pilled ranſacked conſumed aſhes putting edge sword inhabitant thereof maſſacring inhumainely prieſts altar mentz like impetuous torrent cruell attila went ſacked citie rhemes paſſing wholly ouerthwart thence • towne troyes without harme thereto admiring ſanctitie life led lupus biſhop thereof forraging reſt belgicke gaule paris preſerued tyrant cruelty miraculouſly • ame paris miraculouſly preſerued deuout prayer holy virgin geneuieſue patroneſſe pariſians thence went tempeſtuouſly orleans beſiedged preſſed ſo hardly euen next doore deſtruction religious interceſſions aignanus biſhop according city townes deſolated ſudden moment time comfort appea • ed brought • tiu patritiah accompanied theudo king • othes sonne thoriſmond cauſed attila diſcampe purſuing field mauriac whence either ſide departed prepare • fight declared gregory tour • n ſecond booke hiſtory france ſeauenth chapter giueth v vnderſtand aeteus ſuccoured french firſt nameth gothes • ought attila ſeeing armie confuſion good houre ſhifted owne ſafetie periſhing • n day battaile well one ſide hundred foureſcore • houſand men among king vuiſigothes called sigibert 〈◊〉 hierry aetius well ſatisfied winning victory left attila flight vn • eſter himſelfe french gothes gaue apprehenſion people reuolt ſaying thoriſmond behoued make ſpeedily owne countrey fearing leaſt yonger brother hearing tidings father death ſhould poſſeſſe himſelfe kingdome ideo cum velocitate diſceſſit quaſi anticipaturus fratrem prior patris cathedram adepturus simili fran • rum regem dolo fugauit patrician alone rifled eaſe attil • e campe returning rome heaped honor richly laden ſpoyles conquered thus ſee gregory tour ſaith concerning battaile againſt attila king hunnes place fought ſome ſay neere citie toloſa lauragais others ſay towne chaalons champaigne called catalaunum plaine whereof ſeene oratorie chappell erected ſerue remembance thereof others affirme chaalon bourgongne biſhoprick peeredome named cabillonum difficulty grounded paſſage sigebert conſerto praelio campis cathalaunicis pugnatum ad diremptionem noctis caſsiodorus ſpeaking battaile fought yeare grace foure hundred fiftie one conſulſhip emperour marcian adelphius ſaith romani aetio duce gothis auxiliaribus contra attilam campis cathalaunicis pugnauerunt qui virtute gothorum ſuperatus acceſsit authour giueth praiſe honor battaile gothes without ſpeech french fauour oſtrogothes king italie courtier yet notwithſtanding gregory tour long time battaile obſerueth perticularly french came ſuccour romaine hiſtorians doe agree king meroueus childericke sonne french conducted made right wing armie belonging aetius saint gregory tour noteth perticularly place ſaid battaile fought liberata obtentu beati antiſtitis anîani ciuitate aurelia attilam fugant qui mauriacum campum adiens ſe praecingit ad bellum field battaile called mauriac saint maurice cannot directly ſay whether day place ſo named ſtill retaineth ſame betweene orleans bourges mine owne opinion thinke battaile fought plaine field cologne properly called campa catalaunici great deale apparance likelihood chaalons champaigne neere toloſa armie aetius raiſed ſiedge orleans cannot credible armie aetius ſuffiſing raiſe ſiedge orleans cruell attila would giue leaſure winne hundred mile ground orleans toloſa owne pleaſure ſpoyle land vuiſigothes held riuer loire ſo farre pyrenean mountaines haue ſaid according teſtimonie saint gregory tour muſt thought two ſuch puiſſant army could long time without comming handyblowes neere neighbouring field orleans victor prize trophee ſmall purpoſe patrician aetius battaile aduiſe thoriſmond retire haſte toloſa preuention brother battaile bin fought neere toloſa leſſe likelihood trueth ſaying would haue field neere chaalonsthe conſent ancient author concerning attila battaile ſeeing auncient author doe agree attila halfe broken battaile ſpeedily returned ſame way came champaigne trauerſing part duchie bourgongne kingdome trampled bourgongnes belly ſlew king gaudich • would haue hindered paſſage win italie rauaged ſoone priſcus panytes ambaſſador ſent attila emperour theodoſius priſcus panytes greeke author secretarie theodoſius yonger emperour eaſt hee repotteth better hiſtorian perticularities ſpoyles made weſterne empire cruell attila hauing bin ſent ambaſſador ſaid emperor theodoſius himſelfe writeth attila reſolued forradge weſterne empire valentinian quickly leuied armie wherof made lieutenant general •• itois • erguas natition senatour rome prefect gaules pret • rium afterward emperour weſt follow fight attila armie compoſed diuers people ſpecified ſaid panytes drawne relation biſhop auuergne panegericke ſpoken ſaid auitus left charge prefect gaules returned home countrey houſe iam praefecturae perfunctus culmine tandem se gepida trux ſequitur scotum burgundio cogit chunus bellonotus neurus baſtarna toringus bructerus vluoſa quem vel nicer abluit vnda et iam terrificis diffuderat attila turmis campos ſe belga tuos placeth band thoringians bructeres people alemagnefiue hundred thouſand men armie attila inhabiting ſlimie riuer necar attila armie conſiſting fiue hundred thouſand men already rauaged alemagne franconia pilled tongres raced top bottome burnt treuers without finding ſoule reſiſt againſt time merrueus betooke himſelfe guard gaules therefore prepared great number veſſels forreſt hercynia ſay panytes biſhop auuegne prorumpit francus cecidit cito ſecta bipenni hercynia lintres rhenum texuit alno ibant pellitae poſt claſsica romula turmae generally knowne romaine hiſtorians called king france reges pellitos becauſe pleaſed weare garment richly furred yeathe king france vſed weare rich furres garment preciouſly furres ermine letices menuuaire sable martin starrie genettes already belgicke gaule ſerued theater whereon attila made preſentation bloody tragedy putting fire ſword hauing ſacked citie rheims died red blood chiefeſt inhabitant biſhop holy nicaſius ſiſter eutropia much hee would haue done citie troyes prelate thereof withheld blow goe diſcharge rage barbarous furie citie orleans inueſted whole armie made deſolateearneſt prayer hath aſſwaged violent furie bloody tyrant good biſhop aignanus remedied extremity feruent prayer god conſeruation little flocke alſo ſudden ſuccour actius went ſeeke ſo far towne arles prouince part ſo ſecured king french meroueus theodrricke vuiſigothes common cauſe one conſerue conqueſt tooke part romaine although bin ſollicited ioyne attila thought himſelfe ſure enough armes ſaith priſcus panytes freculphus biſhop lyſieux writeth chronogtaphie ſiedge orleans patrician aetius king france aquitaine meroueus ſonne childericke theodoricke thoriſmond ſonne gaue ſo rough charge armie attila braue expert captaine iudged firſt blow proofe could ſtay long without fight made reſolue vpon battaile hotly deliuered without vaine marching campis catalaunicis auitus contrary attempt attila wonne meroueus king frenchthe french ioyne willingly emperours force ſide acquitting name emperour valentinian predeceſſour clodion made conqueſt belonging romaine empire ſide rhine preuailed like manner king vuiſigothes thierrie theodoricke whoſe ſeate royall toloſa biſhop auuergne panegyricke ſaid auitus calleth honor ſake palladiam toloſam palladiam implicitis manibus ſubiere toloſam needed great diſcourſe annimate ſo becauſe spaniſh hiſtorians ſay cruell attila bin incited perſwaded come thundring gaules exterminate principally kingdome vuiſigothes aquitaine king vandales spaine genſericus father hunericus genſericus king vandales spaine hauing taken wife one daughter ſaid theodoricke vuiſigoth vnder couler ſuſpition ſhe would haue giuen poyſon cauſed noſe cut ſo deformed ſent king theodoricke father beſide intereſt preſerue aquitaine romaine emperours giuen predeceſſours could longer keepe themſelues contrary opinion bloody battaile ſoughtthe ſame spaniſh hiſtorians ſay memorable battaile againſt attila fought field maroch without ſpecifying field ſaid maroch moreouer beſide dyed bloody day night meroue •• french giuen camiſado quarter gepides wherein foureſcore ten thouſand men ſlaine place thus ſee hath bin written diuers hiſtorians greekes roman spaniard french concerning battaile againſt ſtout attila meroueus againe valentinian third name ſo wrought youth fearing leaſt aetius ſhould caruing squire ſaid aetius ſtealing behinde ſtoutly kild ſaith saint gregory tour ſecond booke eight chapter french hiſtorie procopius firſt booke vandales hiſtorie deſcribeth theſe ſad accident perticularly affirming death aetius happened contriuing maximus romaine senatour deſcended race tyrant maximus emperour theodoſius elder cauſed dye haue related maximus wife peereleſſe beauty modeſty valentinian became ſo ſtrongly enamoured loud thouſand time deere owne life ought elſe nre ſo neere vertue conſtant aſſaults impertinentbut paſſions fiery flame hardened yee faire chaſte reſolution compaſſed pleaſure force violence like vnto another tarquine chriſtian lucrece returned home houſe ſat downe bemoaned miſery vehement deteſtation husband ſhe thought bin ouerprodigall honour making atque cum ipſo heſperium cecidit regnum nec hactenus valuit releuari yeare grace foure hundred fiftie fiue valentinian conſull eight laſt time anthemius ſlaine meanes maximus whoſe wife dyed conceit griefe regard ſhe bin ſo monſtrouſly diſhonored froiſſard monſtrelet tearmed deflowred death happened ſaid yeare fiftie fiue ſixteenth calends aprill marcellinus come caſsiodorus writeth thus valentinianus imperator occiditur campo martio ab amicis aetij dolo maximi per oſcilan tranſtilam aetij satellite iam percuſſo heraclio spadone valentinian thus ſlaine maximus poſſeſſed himſelfe empire tooke wife eudoxia widdow valentinian creating conſtable colonell infanterie praefect gaules praetorium auitus wee leame biſhop auuergne panegyricke ſpoken ſame auitus — sed perdita cernens terrarum ſpatia princeps iam maximus vnum quod fuit rebus peditum equitumque magiſtrum te ſibi auite legit gaue charge worke peace firmely ſet downe confirmation land already conquered romaine empire ſtranger nation acquitting himſelfe worthily charge well meroueus king french bourgongnons vuiſigothes maximus cleareſighted outwardly maintaining himſelfe empire yet ſtarke blinde himſelfe ſo ſaith procopius could containe tonguethe malice woman implacable one night reuealed maine ſecret wife eudoxia concerning practiſes compaſſing death valentinian wife ariſing breake day diſpoſed ſelfe reuenged wrought ſuch meanes ſhe ſent ſome truſtie friend affrica genſericus king vandales offering empire weſt would come ſpeedily reuenge death husband valentinian preſently ſet ſaile italie got poſſeſſion rome without reſiſtance maximus ſurprized vnawares beaten downe blowes ſtones wherewith mangled piece way able helpe himſelfe according biſhop auuergne writeth epiſtle ad serranum ſecond booke afterward remarkeable leſſon well aduiſed prince neuer ſerue owne turne ſtrange ſuccour vnder colour taking reuenge ordenarily teareth eye body mindes ſeeke ſuch aſſiſtance genſericus robbed burned rome carrying affrica called helpe two daughter eudoxia placida alſo treaſure weſterne emperor ſaith procopius ſecond booke vandale • warres thirtie dayes death tyrant maximus legion gaule exalted auitus empire whereof enioying vntill yeare foure hundred fiftie ſixe hauing reigned ten moneths eight dayes conſtrained diſordered life • renounce empire placentia written gregory tour hiſtorie france ſecond booke eleauenth chapter death empire vacant ten moneths fifteene dayes next ſucceeded maiorian theſe tumult continued weſt empire meroueus ſat hand benummed armes croſſefoulded taking owne aduantage occaſion forelocke poſſeſſed himſelfe extendure countrey betweene riuers somme seine eſpecially citie paris meroueus firſt king made gaule kingdome firſt french king boldly affirmed gaule kingdome happened according romaine hiſtories yeare grace foure hundred fiftie ſixe ioannes varanes conſuls ſaid meroueus preſerue memory king predeceſſours owne ordained ſubdued rhine ſo farre riuer seine afterward wonne gaule ſhould called france firſt entitling france dyed yeare grace foure hundred fiftie nine hauing reigned ten yeares buriall cambraye chap ix childericke sonne succeſſour king meroueus succeſſour sonne childericke generous prince great hope father life time william breton ſpeaking clodion ſaith — ille regia decedens meroueo sceptra reliquit childericum genuit ille clodouei regis pater extitit ſo ſoone ſaw himſelfe abſolutely ſeated throne royall command full power cauſed french looſe good hope conceiued abuſing wiues maides appeared liking drowning himſelfe vice lubricitiesa notorious ſinne king grow forgetfull royall dignity whereat french iuſtly offended rebelled againſt purſued death cauſed leaue france withdraw owne ſafety king thuringe kinſman named biſsinus remained eight whole yeares retreate happened according ſupputation sigibert yeare grace foure hundred threeſcore one third yeare reigne faithfull councellour vnſpeakeable treaſure prince named widomarus oftentimes blamed licentious life guided vtter ruinefaithful councellours iewels prince whoſe diſcreete aduiſe gaue way awhile frenchman furie aſſured promiſe working peace ſo ſoone occaſion offer ſelfe aſſurance returne france wiſe councellour deuided crowne gold betweene ſerued token effect ſaith gregory tour hiſtory france ſecond booke twelfth chapter time french vſed liue time vnder gouernment king elected romaine senator ouer named count gillonus much ſay gouernor soiſſons ſome townes roman yet held belgicke gaule ſo farre riuer loire formerly hath bin reported v gregory tour gillonus bin made maiſter horſe gouernour gaules emperour maiorian count gyles ſome author credit ſeeing himſelfe exalted royall dignitie laboured fauour friendſhip vuiſigothes king maintaine himſelfe therein french ſhould chance change afterward many principall perſons depriued liues politique practiſes others deſpoyled good command vuiſigothes onely preferred count gillonus giuen narbona septimania inſtant time called languedocke widomarus taking hold diſcontentment theirsthe loyall dealing true harted councellor wunne loue french behalfe prince one conſent accepted againe king halfe crowne ſent ſerue aſſured teſtimony peace firmely made childericke returned france reſolued better behauiour yeare grace foure hundred ſixtie nine cum egidius iuſto grauius franco opprimeyet ſaith sigibert perpendens vuidomarus eoſdem franco poenitere ſuper eiecto hilderico reuocat eum clam miſſo diuiſi aurei ſigno egitque vt eiecto egidio ille reſtitueretur regno eight yeares continuance biſsinus king thuringe wonne amorous fauour queene baſsina whereof diſcerned outward appearance woman depriued preſence become extraordinarily affectionate towards ſuch violent manner ſhe forſooke husband went france gueſt childericke preſſing tell induced leaue king husband ſhe made anſwere ſhe compelled thereto certaine foreknowledge ſhe valour aboue prince age ſhe complained croſſing sea ſeeke ſuch worthy man equall world therefore meerely moued owne good opinion ſhe paſſed rhine made ſo long voyage onely dwell childericke accepted making wife marriage clouis aſſiſtance vuiſigothes vntill yeare foure hundred threeſcore fifteene childericke ouercame ranged battaile ſuch diſcomfiture men could hardly get forth preſſe▪ gaue • ſſons kept himſelfe without title crowne imperiall citie treuers 〈◊〉 count gillonus afterward hee conquered ſame gillonus imperiall citie treuers ſo many time wonne reconquered french romaine aime either ſtrange nation make open ſacke ſpoyle thereof conqueſt happened yeare grace foure hundred threeſcore ſixeteene according teſtimonie ſame sigibert toucheth paſſage along thus franci treuerim ciuitatem ſuper moſellam capiunt childericke become maiſter realme france ſo farre riuer seine ſome townes excepted went beſiedged citie paris renowned time iulius caeſar well affected abiding iulian apoſtata exalted emperour therein good pleaſure heere appertaineth v doe thing contrary theſe word one troupe enuious mutinous raſh full ſpleenethe beſt company free frō one degenerate minde among cried fooliſh brauerie lifting vp memoriae hluduicus rex quem vt praedixi de sacro baptiſmi ſonte ſuſcepi donare dignatus eſt vt de eo facerem quod ipſe voluiſſem tibi haeredi meae eccleſiae ſupra memoratae iubeo thuribulum imaginatum gondencus king bourgongne foure ſonnes wit gondebauld godegiſillus chilpericus godomarus gondebauld eldeſt ſonne ſlew brother chilpericus threw wife riuer roſne rhene great ſtone h • r necke ſhee drowned chilpericus left two daughter eldeſt whereof named mucurna gombauld made religious profeſſed nunne youngeſt called crothilda hee kept neere vnto himſelfe aurelianus oftentimes went came bourgongne maſter hauing ſeene young princeſſe endued exquiſite beauty body ſo conſequently ſoulethe faireſt body doe vſually contain faireſt ſoules according teſtimony diuine plato within faireſt body doe ordinarily dwell faireſt ſoules made ſuch report maſter reſolued make demand king bourgongne accorly aurelianus gombauld durſt vſe deniall hauing affianced ancient cuſtome french brought city soiſſons marriage ſolemnized magnificence ſimply ſpeaketh gregory tour ſecond booke eight twenty chapter without ſpecifying ancient cuſtome marriage obſerued gaules french fredegarus scholaſticke facto ſi eis conuenit viduam accipiat ſecond paragraphe ſame fortie ſixe title de reippis hee eſpouſed widdow without paying price ſhould pay neereſt kinſman partie deceaſed amercement ſpecified law name oriflambe vulgarly hiſtory lord de ioinuille hiſtorians banner penys vexillum beati dionyſij deſcribed william breton eleauenth booke philippides aſt regi ſatis eſt tenues criſpare per aura vexillum ſimplex cendato ſimplice iextum splendoris rubei letania qualiter vti eccleſiana ſolet certis ex diebus quod quum flammas habeat omnia vulgariter aurea nomen omnibus bellis habet omnia signa praeire quod regi praeſtare ſolet dionyſius abbas ad bellum quotiens ſumptis proficiſcitur armis great annales denys deſcribing battaile caſſell flanders king phillip de valois ſixt name informeth v battaile fought morrow feaſts iames chriſtopher yeare 1215 ſaith clamatur vbique per campos arma arma viri clangunt tuba reuertuntur cohortes quae iam pontem tranſierunt reuocatur vexillum beati dionyſij quod omnes praecedere bello debebat another place interea adueniunt legiones communiarum quae fere vſque ad hoſpitia proceſſerant vexillum b dionyſij accurrunt quantocyus ad aciem regis vbi videbant signum regale vexillum videlicet floribus lilij diſtinctum thus diſcerne difference betweene banner denys royall one rigordus affirmeth ſemed floures de luce whereas denys made ſimple red cauſed hallowed oriflambe abbot gaue meſsire peter de villiers elder tooke accuſtomed oath kept almoſt whole yeare flemmings turning rebel againſt lewes countthe flemmings rebel againſt lord count lewes father law monſieur phillip france tearmed hardie duke bourgongne ſaid count requeſted king charles ſixt soueraign lord lend ſuccor whereby might reduce rebellious ſubiects duety obedience king hauing leuied armie readineſſe march away went denys worthily welcomed abbot religious brother place morrow morning maſſe ſolemnely ſung sermon preached reuerend diuine holy reliques ſet vpon altar king according laudable manner predeceſſours without chaperon without girdle performed prayer deuotions offering lord like done cauſed oriflambe brought deliuered aged knight valiant gentleman named meſsire peter de villiers elder tooke oath ſuch caſes required king returned bo •• de vincennes yeare 1382 yeare king ready giue battaile philip arteuelle flemmingstwo ſtrange accident • happening ioyning two army pont de commines two thing happened ſeemed ſomewhat marueilous one came ſuch flight rauens engirt hoaſte either ſide wonderfull neuer ceaſing flickering flying ſpace fiue ſixe dayes ayre ſo darke charged ſtormes hardly could one man ſee another king knew flemmings came fight made kinde promiſe would fight cauſing people march oriflambe diſplayed ſooner diſplayed storie ſaith aire defectus inguinariae pectis curatio scrophularum wicked foule diſeaſe hath many latine greeke name chaeradae sodellae struma scrophulae beſide clouis king succeſſors touching throates ſo diſeaſedthe word vſed king touching diſeaſe vſed theſe word king doe day king toucheth thee god cure thee lewes ninth name added thereto ſigne croſſe king predeceſſours vſed doe learne guilla • de nangis liues lewes eldeſt sonne phillip hardie king france third name tangendo infirmitates quae vulgo sodellae vocantur ſuper quibus curandi franciae regibus dominus contulit gratiam ſingularem pius rex ſpeaking lewes modum hunc ſigne croſſe added king lewes praeter caeteros voluit obſeruari cum enim alij reges praedeceſſores ſui tangendo ſolummodo locum morbi verba ad haec appropriata conſueta proferrent quae quidem verba sanctum atque catholica ſunt nec facere conſueniſſent aliquod ſignum crucis ipſe lewes ſuper conſuetudinem aliorum hoc addidit quod dicendo verba ſuper locum morbi ſanctae crucis ſignaculum imprimebat vt ſequens curatio virtuti crucis potius attribueretur quae regiae dignitati yet notwithſtanding haue ſeene ſome ſuch diſeaſed perſons handled king henry third henry great famous memory king lewes thirteenth reigning onely touch euill pronouncing word remembred iacobus valdeſius spaniſh doctor tract hee wrote concerning dignity king kingdome spaine compelled ſubſcribe truth touching excellency king france healing dangerous diſeaſe howbeit according naturall diſpoſition nation ſo wretched ſickneſſe cannot exceed true meanes indeed laboureth ſubtilly tarniſh deface glory french vttermoſt auouching power curing proceeded purity ſweetneſſe ayre france contrariwiſe heauenly grace fauour giuen noble king thereof non deſunt qui detrahere gloriae gallorum velint id euenire dicentes occaſione aeris gallici • urandis strumis ſalubris ita omnes aerem mutantes ad regionem galliae venientes valetudinem recuperare sed ego ſentio id accidere gratia conceſſa deo optimo maximo e francis firſt telleth v battell marignano field saint bridget place famous ouerthrow buriall ſixteene thouſand fiue hundred switzers ſlaine field king francis became maſter duchie millaine seigneury departure hee handled healed diſeaſed king euill chappell ſaid pope pallace great amazement holy father italian came ſee wonder biſhop poland cured king euill among reſt biſhop polonia cured came expreſſely effect millaine thence bologna commendatory letter king poland lord soueraigne prince vnfortunate day pa • ia ſo fatall france ſurprizall ſame king francis great prince tranſported spaine hee vſed like barbarian rigour charles fift vaſſall liedgeman county flanders artois ſaid king rendring good euill healed spaniard infected loathſome diſeaſe wherewith thoſe people troubled beyond world bad entertainment king goodneſſe extended spaniard ſole ſubiect learned laſcaris make epigram whereby hee touched quicke charles fift ingratitude ſmall reſpect honour offered aeſculapius people prince soueraigne lord ergo manu admota ſanat rex charadasthe epigram laſcarit againſt charles fift est que captiuus superis gratus vt ante fuit iudicio talus regum ſanctiſsime qui te arcent inuiſos ſuſpicor eſſe deis come king regall right prerogatiue gregory tour ſecond booke thirty eight chapter hiſtory france ſpeaking preſents king clouis receiued anaſtaſius emperour eaſt ſaith aſcenſo equo aurum argentumque itinere illo quod inter portam atrij eccleſiam ciuitatis eſt praeſentibus populis manu propria ſpargens voluntate benigniſsima erogauit hauing receiued church martin tour mounted pariter atque futuris notum ſit quod no inſpeximus chartas patris noſtri noſtram quibus continebatur quod no hominibus epiſcopi pariſienſis extra pariſius non poteramus talliam accipere vel exactionem facere quae excederet numerum ſexaginta librarum pariſienſium nec illam accipere poteramus niſi statuto tempore epiſcopo debitam quia verò vacante ſede pariſienſi defuncto bonae memoriae mauritio quondam epiſcopo pariſienſi hominibus epiſcopi accipimus ſummam ducentarum quadraginta librarum aut ampliùs vltra praedictas sexaginta libra ad petitionem dilecti conſanguinei fidelis noſtri odonis pariſienſis epiſcopi conceſsimus quod quando regalia manum noſtram vel ſucceſſorum nostrorum deuenient ea quae no aut miniſteriales noſtri accipiendo vltra praedictam ſummam ſexaginta librarum exigere fecimus nullum epiſcopo pariſienſi vel eccleſiae pariſienſi poſterum inferre praeiudicium aut grauamen nec hominibus epiſcopi extra pariſius ſicut ſupradictum eſt no vel ſucceſſores noſtri aliquid de cetero poterimus accipere vel requirere vltra praedictam ſummam ſexaginta librarum pro tallia vel exactione quod vt perpetuum c datum apud ſanctum germanum laïa anno domini milleſimo ducenteſimo letter patent ego ludouicus dei gratia francorum rex notum facimus vniuerſis clericos noſtros carnotenae ciuitatis existentes adhuc • n deſolatione quam acciperant ex morte bonae memoriae epiſcopi goſleni noſtram adiuiſſe • iam ſerenitatem humiliter expostulaſſe quantinus praeceptum aui noſtri regis phi • ippi philip firſt name no iamdictae eccleſiae confirmaremus • enor igitur priuilegij talis eſſe dignoſcitur regem philippum notum facere vniuerſis regno franciae per futura tempora ſucceſſuris quod domnus yuo ſanctae carnotenſis ec • leſiae venerabilis epiſcopus humili deuotione celfitudinem ſuae ſerenitatis adierit ob • ixè deprecans vt prauam conſuetudinem domibus epiſcopalibus eiuſdem eccleſiae comite henrico cognomento stephano adela vxore eius conceſsiene filicrum ſuorum guillelmi theobaldi odonis stephani remiſſam▪ libertatem praedictis • mibus rebus eiſdem collectis à praedictis comitibus collatam concederet et ſua pragmatica sanctione firmaret cuius pio deſiderio aſſentiens aequiſsima poſtulat • aurem inclinans ſecundum tenorem ſcripti quod de praedictis rebus praetaxati comites • ieri decreuerunt ſuae sacrae maieſtatis auctoritate rex praetaxatas à praua conſuetudine liberauit domum ſcilicet domus eiuſdem ferrum plumbum vitrum lignum lapides caeteramque ſupellectilem ſcilicet ſtabulas ſcamna ſcabella vaſa vinaria lectos nec • coquinas horrca granaria cellaria torcularia furnos furnorumque domos ſiue vrbe ſiue extra vrbem ſyluas vt non vendantur nec ſuccidantur nec dentur ann • quoque vinum foenum oues boues caetera animalia omniaque reliqua mobilis que congregata ſunt vel collecta fuerunt ſiue vrbe ſiue extra vrbem ante obitum diſceſſum epiſcopi cuiuslibet intacta manere firmauit illis profutura quibus epiſcopium reſeruare vel donare ſeu per ſe ſeu per oechonomum ſuum eadem sacrum maieſtis dicti decreuerit vel maiores perſonae eccleſiae ſi id epiſcopo aliqua occaſione praeuento facere non licuerit concedimus etiam vt exactio quae defunctis epiſcopis vel diſcendentibus fien ſolet seruientes epiſcopi vel ruſticos de caetero nunquam fiat haec omnia ſicut pr • dictis comitibus conceſſum eſt firmatum ipſe praedictus rex vt praedictum eſt ce • ceſsit per pragmaticam sanctionem ſuam firmauit no autem clericorum eiuſdem eccleſiae aud • ta ſuſcepta poſtulatione haec omnia eis eundem modum immobilit • atque perpetu • ſicut praedictus auus noſter philippus rex francorum conceſsimus noſtri ſigilli auctoritate ſirmauimus nominis caractere teſtificati ſumus datu • publicè pariſius anno domini▪ 1155 adſtantibus quorum nomina ſubſcripta ſunt ſ • gna signum comit • bleſenſis theobaldi dapiferi noſtri guidonis buticularij matthei camerarij mathaei conſtabularij data per manum hugonis cancellarij another charter granted ſaid countthe charter ſaid count henry stephen chartres regiſtred remarkeable neuerleſſe paſſe ouer becauſe would ſeeme long tedious ſame king lewis yonger called deuout vulgarly pittifull exempted gratified ſame ſubiect church • aon letter patent regiſtred parliament heere may reade ego ludouicus dei gratia francorum rex notum facimus vniuerſis praeſentibus futuris quod per conſilium fidelium noſtrorum nobis aſsidentium pro humili •• renda prece epiſcopi laudunenſis magiſtri galteri de mauritannia de mortaign mortagne grangias curtes carrucas greges armenta de quibuſcunque animalibus vineas de campo britonis de clauſo iuxta brolium ipſum brolium vineas de p • aco alias etiam vineas quaſcunque plantauerit ſiue acquiſiuerit omnino omne inſta • mentum ſuum libertate donauimus perpetuum ipſius etiam petitione omnes eiuſdem ſucceſſores ea auctoritate poſuimus vt tempore vindemiarum ad reficiendas vineas de fructu earum tantum reſidui conſeruetur cultoribus reddatur quod earum culturae ſ • ſficiat libertate quorum donauimus domos epiſcopi de lauduno quaſcunque extra l • duno quaſcun que extra laudunum habet quidquid eiſdem domibus conſiſtit de l • gno filo de ferro vitro aere de quacunque alia materia hoa autem • rali regio pro euidentia rerum poſterum pro conſeruando eiuſdem libertatis •• tu inſerere dignum duximus quod decedens epiſcopus ſicut teſtatus fuerit ratum eri • et ſi deceſſerit inteſtatus quod abſit regij iuris erit aurum eius argentum totum • nona tota excepta illa quam custodes granchiarum magistri carrucarum retinebunt 〈◊〉 ſeminandos agros ad ſufficienter ſuſtentandum ſe ſeruientes neceſſarios ſibi • imalia ſua similiter vinum ab inteſtato epiſcopo remanens totum regij iuris erit excep • vino illo quod de vineis acquiſitis vel plantatis à praefato epiſcopo fuerit quod ſanè vi • noſtrum non erit▪ ſed inde praenuncupati epiſcopi ſoluentur debita ſinulla ſunt reſeruabitur vinum ſucceſſoribus porrò poſt deceſſum epiſcopi epiſcopatu veniente • regiam seruientes de parte regis venientes non ſtabunt domibus lauduni nec • domibus vbi munitiones non erunt ſed alijs locis vbi munitiones ſunt ipſi miniſtr • regij munitionib▪ manebunt ad cuſtodiam earum diſtrahendis rebus epiſcopi pr • dicti quas libertate donauimus vel ordinando vel vſus ſuos aſſumendis poteſta • carebunt ſed illi potius seruientes miniſteriales seruientes ſuch dayes called sergeant qui vita epiſcopi eam ſortiti ſunt adminiſtrationem retinebunt eandem ſeorſum domibus grangijs epiſcopalibus manebunt dum manu regia epiſcopatus fuerit brolium nec vendere nec donare nec aliquo modo diminuere poterimus ſi vacauerit ſedes meſsionum tempore cuſtodes grangiarum retinebunt quod ſufficiat ſeminandis agris paſcendis conducendis bubulcis paſtoribus miniſtris animalibus caeterum regij iuris eſt et ſi vacauerit sedes vindemijs vinum de taxone de tallijs vinagium quod per pagum colligitur caeterique omnis redditus praeter ea quae libertate donauimus ſimiliter regij iuris erit vt autem hoc donum noſtrum poſterum ratum ſit fixum permaneat c actum pariſius anno incarnationis domini milleſimo centeſimo quinquageſimo octauo regni verò noſtri viceſimo ſecundo ſame king beginning voyage holy land among infidel miſcreants remitted biſhop chaalons champaigne right regalewhen chriſtian force went expedition regard victual kinred ſent campe neere verdune followeth copie ſame lvdouicus dei gratia francorum rex dux aquitaniae notum facimus vniuerſis c inter vniuerſa quae magnitudo regalis agere debet nihil glorioſius eſſe dignoſcitur quam quod eccleſiarum tranquilitati ſtudet poſterum prouiderethe king free remiſsion regal right libertatem earum ad honorem nominis domini noſtri ieſuchriſti inceſſanter angere huius rei gratia dilectiſsimi noſtri bartholomei catalaunenſis epiſcopi precibus annuentes ei ſucceſſoribus ſuis epiſcopis perpetuum condonamus ne poſt deceſſum catalaunenſis epiſcopi ſicut antiquae conſuetudinis huc vſque tenor habuerat domibus epiſcopalibus quidquid ligneum aut ferreum ſiue per no ſiue per miniſteria le noſtros de caetero capiamus animalia quoque epiſcopi caetera omnia quaecunque ad ſupellectilem domorum epiſcopalium pertin • dignoſcuntur ſub eadem immunitate concludimus praeter annonam vinum aurum argentum quae omnia iuxta vetuſtam conſuetudinem manu poteſtate regia retinemus quod ſi de praefatae sedis epiſcopus ante obitum ſuum ſub legitimo teſtamento diſpoſuerit illius ordinationi contradicere nolumus vt hoc igitur perpetuum c actum caſtro apud verdunum anno ab incarnatione domini milleſimo centeſimo quadrageſimo septimo regni noſtri vndecimo quando viam sanctae hieroſolymitanae expeditionis inuimus bartholomeus cancellarius sacri noſtri palatij subſcripſit ſame king letter patent ſeene ſaid court regiſters concerning regall right biſhopricke menda geuaudan suffragan biſhopricke belonging archbiſhopricke bourges biſhops called themſelues lord soueraignes count • primacie aquitaine biſhops ſaid place ſmall towne ſeated neere riuer ol ſides engirt mountaines seuenes languedocke betweene biſhops montpellier niſmes puy velay flour haue heretofore tearmed themſelues lord soueraignes land belonging dioceſſe therefore made ſolemne feſtiuals scepter gold carried likewiſe would lay vpon altar celebrated pontificalibus vnto day beare title count geuaudan epiſcopall houſe beſide place citie menda ſeene many armes biſhops thereof couered count circle crowne others haue aloft miter one ſide helmet croſier midſt ſhew lord spirituall temporall countrey afterward king became maiſter thereof conſent biſhops place ſome manner ſmall citie menda hath armes leſeu azur à vne à l antique one would ſay mimatus vn soleil en chef pour deuiſe lentour tenebrae eam non comprehenderunt armes ſmall citie menda caſe altered becauſe ouercome hereſie hath proued ruine citie biſhoppes church one richeſt france letter patent king lewes ſeauenth ſent biſhop aubert homage ſaid countie geuaudan king letter patent directed aubert biſhop menda lvdouicus dei gratia francorum rex adelberto venerabili gabalorum epiſcopo omnibus succeſſoribus ſuis perpetuum longe eſt à memoria omnium mortalium noſtri temporis quod aliquis epiſcopus gabalorum ad curiam anteceſſorum noſtrorum regum francorum venerit eorum ſubditionem agnouerit fidelitatem eis fecerit qua • uis tota terra illa aditu difficilima montuoſa epiſcoporum poteſtate ſemper extiterit non tantum ad faciendum eccleſiaſticam cenſuram ſed ad iudicandum ingladio ſuper illes quos culpa ſua monſtrabat ſic redarguendos vir autem illuſtris iam dictus adelbertus epiſcopus religioſe cogitans materiales gladij iuſtitias ad virgam regni pertinere noſtram ſerenitatem adijt pariſius ibidem praeſentia totius baronia noſtrae cognouit epiſcopatum ſuum de corona regni noſtri eſſe ſe nobis ſubdens nobis regno celebriter tacto euangelio ſacro fidelitatem fecit quod ſane factum ad nullum detrimentum ad nullum prorſus priuationem hactenus habitae poteſtatis poſterum conuerti volentes notam facimus vniuerſis praeſentibus futuris quod eccleſiae glorioſi martyris priuati saint priuat patron citie menda yet neuertheleſſe cathedrall dedicated virgin marie epiſcopis omnibus venerabili amico noſtro aldeberto • nice ſuccedentibus totum gabalorum epiſcopatum cum regalibus ad noſtram coronam pertinentibus ex integro concedimus vt libere quiete perpetuum poſsideant auctoritate regia confirmamus ne autem de cetero aliquis ſucceſſorum noſtrorum moleſtiam viole • tiam aliquo modo inferre conetur pacis quieti pra • ictae eccleſiae regia benignitate prouidentes ipſam liberam ob omni exactione immunem eſſe concedimus vt ſic temporibus cunctis permaneat decernimus ſubtus inſcripto raminis noſtris charactere francorum poteſtatem habens 〈◊〉 decanothe publique acknowledgement elect biſhop maſcon vniuerſo capitulo matiſconenſi per litteras eiuſdem decani capituli patentes videlicet quod quidquid facerem preſentia domini regis ratum haberent perpetuum obſeruarent recognoui ius domini regis francorum quod habet regalibus matiſconenſis eccleſiae ſcilicet quod mortuo epiſcopo matiſconenſi vel quotieſcunque ſedes matiſconenſis vacauerit omnia regalia omnes prouentus regalium exiſtentes regno franciae libere ſunt domini regis francorum ſicut epiſcopus libere poſsidebat et ſi quis epiſcopus matiſconenſis deceſſerit inteſtatus quod omnia tam mobilia quam prouentus omnes ſunt dominij regis francorum integre abſolute quia vero decanus capitulum matiſconenſe contradixerunt nuntio domini regis francorum odoni ſcilicet clementi archidiacono pariſienſi clerico ſuo regalia mobilia morte r epiſcopi ego emendaui pro decano capitulo dominus rex francorum hanc emendam miſit ſummonitione ſua quod vt ratum firmumque permaneat hoc ſcriptum ſigilli noſtri munimine fecimus roborari actum pariſius anno domini • lleſimo ducenteſimo primo menſe martio vpon refuſall made deane chapter maſcon archdeacon paris eudes clearke chappell ſaid phillip auguſtus regales well vacant prebendary moueables laſt deceaſed biſhop ſaid king reuoked power electing new biſhopthe king reuoked power electing new biſhop yet reſtored owne charge make amends according owne liking ſpecified letter patent ſent ſaid deane chapter ſuch manner followeth philippus dei gratia francorum rex nouerint vniuerſi praeſentes pariter futuri quod quotienſcumque epiſcopus matiſconenſis morietur vel quotienſcum que sedes matiſconenſis eccleſiae vacauerit capitulum matiſconenſe nobis licentiam de electione facienda requiſierit eidem ſine contradictione eligendi licentiam concedemus si vero epiſcopus eiuſdem eccleſiae inteſtatus deceſſerit omnia mobilia quae ipſe vel per ſe vel per alium regno noſtro poſsidebat libere integre noſtra erunt si vero idem epiſcopus noſtra licentia teſtamentum fecerit per teſtimonium bonorum virorum de mobilibus quae ipſe vita ſua poſsidebat no contra idem teſtamentum nequaquam veniemus praeterea ſciendum eſt quod omnia regalia omnes prouentus regalium poſt mortem epiſcopi matisconenſis quandiu ſedes dictum vacauerit vbicunque ſint regno noſtro quiete pacifice poſsidebimus no eadem regalia eo ſtatu puncto poſtquam ad manum noſtram deuenerint ſine violentia contrectabimus quomodo praedeceſſor epiſcopus matiſconenſis ea contrectauerit quod vt firmum ſit c actum pariſius anno domini milleſimo ducenteſimo primo menſis aprilis regni noſtri viceſimo quarto ſame philip auguſtus warre againſt elected emperour otho ferrand portugall count flanders iohn richard regales eadē ſede vacante quotiens quandiu vacauerit libere teneant conſeruent ad opus epiſcopi ſucceſſoris et quod eccleſia praedicta à nobis rem • ta cumfinio regni imperij ſita eſt ad periculum vitandum cōcerning k lewes fraeno iuſti regiminis longo tempore diſſoluta fuit terra burgundiae illis qui ea erant alicuius potentiae licuit impugna • e inter ſe decertare pauperes opprimere eccleſiarum bona vaſtare no propter • antam indignitati malitiam zelo dei commoti terram burgundiae cum copijs regni • nteruenimus obtentu faciend vindictas reformandi pacem patria notum itaque facimus vniuerſis praeſentibus futuris quod cum ſederemus cabillonis ad indic •• dum ſuper negotijs ad cognoſcendum cauſas diuerſas inter alias audiuimus quer im •• iam eccleſiae matiſconenſis contra comitem girardum vianenſem ipſe non pot •• aſſerere ſe ſuper eccleſiam aliquid iuris habere ſiue epiſcopi ſiue capitulis terri • •• que hominibus enſueth proceeding k philip auguſtus philip auguſtus execution ſaid francorum rex c nouerint vniuerſi praeſentes pariter f • turi quod cum dilaecta fidelis noſtra blanca comitiſsa campaniae citata eſſet per ducem • urgundiae mathaeum de montemaurencij wilelmum de barris vt cariam noſtram veniret iuri paritura de querelis quas erardus de brena philippa que dicitur vxer eius contra eandem comitiſſam eius filium proponebant ſuper eo quod ipſe erardus eadem philippa petebant nobis quod no reciperemus eiuſdem erardi h • magium de comitatu campaniae ſicut come henricus nepos noſteri quem ipſa philipp • patrem ſuum eſſe dicebat inde ſaiſitus fuerat tandem apud melodunum noſtra pr • ſentia conſtituti praedicta blanca comitiſſa campaniae theobaldus filius eius ex 〈◊〉 parte praedicti erardus de brena philippa ex altera requirentes ſuper hoc fibi fieri iudiciam iudicatum eſt baronibus nostris videlicet rhemenſi archiepiſcopo willelmo lingonenſi willelmo catalaunenſi philippo beluacenſi r nouiomenſi epiſcopis odone duce burgundiae paribus regni noſtri alijs multis ſcilicet willelmo com p •• ti • roberto comite drocenſi r comite britanniae guidone comite sancti pauli willelmo de • upibus seneſcallo andegaui willelmo comite iouiniaci ioanne comite bellimontis roberto comite de alenconia etiam quibuſdam epiſcopis videlicet antiſiodori car • otenſi syluanectenſi lexonienſi nobis audientibus iudicium approbantibus quod hommagium erardi de brena vel dictum philippae de comitatu campaniae nullate • u recipere debebamus quamdiu comitiſſa blanca theobaldus filius eius vellent ius • acere curia noſtra perſequi quod vſus conſuetudo franciae talis eſt quod ex • aliquis ſaiſitus eſt de feudo per dominum feodi dominus feodi non debet alium reci • ere hominem de eodem feodo quamdiu ille qui ſaiſitus eſt de feodo per dominum feo • • paratus ſitius faecere curia domini feodi perſequi et quia comitem theobaldum quondam nepotem noſtrum patrem iſtius theobaldi per aſſenſum baronum • oſtrorum nullo contradicente recipimus hominem de comitatu campaniae briae • icut pater eius come henricus tenens fuerat poſt deceſſum dicti comitis theobaldi • ecipimus blancam comitiſſam de codem comitatu foeminem noſtram ſicut de baillio praeterea theobaldum filium eius ſaluo baillio praeterea theobaldum filium eius • luo baillio matris ſuae nullo contradicente de iure non debemus diſſaiſire blancam comi • iſſam vel theobaldum filium eius de comitatu campaniae briae quamdiu parati eſſent • u facere curia nostra perſequi et ipſa coram nobis alijs baronibus noſtris • ſemper obtulit hoc autem iudicium factum fuit nihil amplius quaeſierunt de praedicta • omitiſſa eius filio ſic ſine die receſſerunt order giuen melun dated moneth iuly 1216 • entence remarkeable court repreſenting king moſt ſacred • erſon rendreth reaſon iudgethe court preſenteth king royall perſon likewiſe practiſed pronoun • ing proclaiming criminall iudgements demonſtration giuen • people ſome reparation forfeit wherein criminall condemned ſhew kingdome ruled iuſtice open whole world • nthralled vnder yoake voluntary abſolute power hath • language haue ſo tyrannicall word sic volo ſic iubeo ſit pro ratione voluntasthe abſurdity tyrannicall power great equity declareth ſelfe propoſitions error court • ffecteth much rather retract sentence iudgements confeſſing freely • hat ſhe hath erred doe iniuſtice behoueth moreouer obſerue time king philip auguſtus • number peeres france firmely ordered twelue iuſtified • hiſtorian england mathew paris monke albanes england • ued time king lewes author informeth vsat time number peer concluded • ffaires holy land wherein ſaid king lewes queene blanche • mother time regent france deriue ſome commodity • ing england henry third would needes render duchy • andy decree ſaid phillip auguſtus court furniſhed • eeres beene confiſcated king iohn without land cauſes whereof • ſpeake heereafter againſt reſtitution oppoſed themſelues prince blood peeres • nd parlements france theſe remarkeable tract si velit domina blanchia • c facere nunquam regni francorum vniuerſitas hoc concedet oppoſition france againſt reſtoring duchy normandie abſit enim vt duodecim • arium iudicium quo iuſte abdicatur rex anglorum vt priuatur normannia caſſetur 〈◊〉 pro friuolo habeatur ſent tell king england behalfe • prince bernage ſay baronage france dreadfull oath quod antequam rex angliae ſperata reciperet oporteret eum neceſſario per mille lancearum • ucrones poſt earum fragmenta per totidem gladios cruentandos tranſitum facere mi • tarem king lewes conferring king england henry thirdspeeches two kinge meeting come expr • ſſely viſit paris yeere 1254 vtinam ait rex fran • rum duodecim pares franciae baronagium mihi conſentirent certe amici eſſemus • ſſolubiles mathew paris greateſt lord ſacred praeſenti inſerimus paginae archiepiſcopus rhemenſis qui regem francorum coeleſti conſecrat chriſmate qu • propter rex francorum regum omnium cenſetur digniſsimus spaniſh writer auouch paſſage eſt omnium franciae parium primus excellentiſsimus epiſcopus nouiomenſ •• peeres france eccleſiaſticall perſons qui eſt come palatinus epiſcopus beluacenſis qui eſt come palatinus epiſcopus c • talaunenſis epiſc • pu langonenſis qui quamuis pauper ſit dignus tamen habetur epiſcopus laudun • nſis qui dux est come ratione sancti rhemigij ad quem deuoluta f •• illa praeclara haereditas 〈◊〉 maio conuentus ibidem habitus eſt quo inter ceteras barbarorum legationes que ſua ſponte venerunt duo fratres reges vvilſorum controuerſiam inter ſe de regno habentes ad regis praeſentiam venerunt quorum nomina ſunt meligaſtus celeadratus erant enim filij regis vvilſorum liubi qui licet cum fratribus ſuis regnum ſuum diuiſum teneret tamen propterea quod natu maior eſſet ad eum totius regni ſumma perti • ebat illo occiſo commiſſo cum orientalibus obotritis praelio vuilſi filium cius meligadum qui maior erat regem ſibi constituunt sed cum eius ſecundum ritum gentis commiſſum ſibi regnum parum digne adminiſtraret illo abiecto iuniori fratri regium hono • em detulerunt quam ob cauſam ambo ad regis imperatoriſque praeſentiam venerunt quos cum audiſſet ſtatuit vt iunior frater delatam papae ſucceſſoribus tuis omnem obedientiam honorifacentiam exhibeo quam deuoti catholici imperatores conſueuerunt sedi apoſtolicae exhibere stabo etiam ad conſilium arbitrium tuum de bonis france excelleth ſurpaſſeth salomon ſo conſequently king spaine king prince earth wee haue meanes paſſe encreaſeth commeth spaine becauſe ſterrilitie soyle cauſeth continuall carriage thither france corne wine cloth thing moſt neceſſary life • man king spaine want qualifying ſtiling themſelues king leon arragon nauarre valencia granada toledo murcia cordoua portugall algaraes long thred like title prouinces hath cauſed ſuch haue ſeene countrey thinke spaine number time farre greater kingdome france — sed non ego credulus illis experience hath ſuffered ſee contrary verifie plainely palpably way compared france except extre • ignorance whoſoeuer ſhall meaſure fertile prouinces monarch lillie prouence languedocke guienne poictu bretaigne normandie champaig • bourgongne lyonnois daulphine without making mention prouinces ſeated midſt haue named would make many kingdomes king gouerned themſelues according manner spa • finde without doubt france latitude longitude excelleth much spaine admirable france antiquity greatneſſe ſerued ſpacious field moſt noble ſubiect spaniſh poet lucane ſhewhow caeſar became lord romane empire caeſar became maſter romane empire meanes wealthy prouinces whereas hath ſpoken like spaine admireth earneſtly extendure preferreth good right kingdom ſpacious world — sparſas per gallica rura cohortes euocat romam motis petit vndique ſignis deſeruere cauo tentoria fixa lemano beginneth suetia watered lake geneua lozana • unneth thence mountaines vaulga make ſeparation • ands germany france caſtraque quae vogeſi curuam ſuper ardua rupem thorow • auoy taketh largeneſſe montmelian thwarting granoble roman • aulphine ſome mile thence ſinketh ſelfe riuer rhoſne • rhone ariſing alpes calleth amnem famae maioris plinie 〈◊〉 naturall hiſtory noteth originall ſpring riuer rhoſne • ſwalloweth looſeth ſelfe iſara saona thus galliarum fertiliſ • mu rhodanus fluuius ex alpibus ſe rapiens per lacum lemanum ſegnemque deferens • rarim nec minus ſe ipſo torrentem iſaram becauſe iſara hath courſe impetu • u rhoſne thence againe poet hath another leap rouergne whereof rhodes 〈◊〉 biſhops see ciuitas ruthenorum soluuntur flaui longa ſtatione countrey liege writeth bello gallico thus lucan obſerueth —nimiumque rebellis neruius caeſi pollutus ſanguine cottae vpon one thred fileth treuers ſometime capitall city gaules wormes holland tu quoque latatus conuerti praelia treuir et qui te laxis imitantur sarmata braccis vangiones batauique truce • abited scythian poland manner thence hee commeth garden france poictou tourainethe garden thoſe preceptsthe druides receiued precept gomer cauſed exactly kept obſerued gaules vpon preuarication grounded iuſtice pollicie ciuile criminall made capable nation earth gathering thoſe diuine seedes reuealed great denys made alſo ſo apt receiuing doctrine wherby gaules moment became chriſtians firme conſtant faith ieſus chriſt without leaſt feare torment firme conſtancie caſe foundationthe firme conſtancie gaules orthodoxe religion originall wellſpring gallicane church libertie biſhops whereof ſhewed themſelues buckler orthodoxe religion againſt heretiques prouinces greece italie spaine hauing bin infected hereſie gaules onely remained conſtant without wauering catholique faith foure hundred yeares together vntill ſuch time diuell enemie man cauſed ſowne field bleſſing darnell moſt wicked deteſtable doctrine one vigilantius tauerner natiue calahorra spaine learne learned father church hierome writing againſt vigilantius gallia ſola monſtris caruit cum vigilantius immo dormitanus caupo calaguritanus ſubito exorſus eſt c heretiques ſhoote vp one night like muſhromes firme conſtancie catholique faith french church hath alwaies preference precedency aboue chriſtendome holy see rome vpon conſtancy grounded liberty thereof ſpeake three word conſiſt maintaining authority holy see apoſtolique vniuerſall councels againſt tolleration france thoſe thing pope made men would innouate caſe sacred parlaments france namely paris ephores rather areopagite power ruled according holy councels abuſes rooted great liberty church france againſt ſome pope proceedingsthe liberty french gallicane church ſo great matter meruaile pope preoccupated paſſions ſending fulmination againſt france haue longer bin acknowledged ſuch men haue ſtept obedience well prohibiting tranſport gold siluer kingdome prouiſion benefice caſe remitted ordenaries kingdome france moſt auncient priuiledge hath power holy seate rome vacant cardinal agreeing election popethe kingdome france hath power elect pope make choyce one france pope gregory ninth dead cardinal rome long time proceeding election another king lewes yeare one thouſand two hundred forty three ſent ambaſſadours rome ſignifie declare cardinal ſhould ſpeedily without day proceede election pope thorow default negligence prelate france ſhould elect one beyond mountaines according auncient liberty gallicane church per idem tempus miſerunt franci ſolemnes nuncio ad curiam romanam ſignificantes perſuadendo praeciſe efficaciter vt ipſi cardinales papam ritè eligentes vniuerſali eccleſiae ſolatium paſtorale maturius prouiderent vel ipſi franci propter negligentiam corum de ſibi eligendo prouidendo ſummo pontifice citra monte cui obedire tenerentur quantecyus contrectarent et hoc audacter ſignificabant confiſi de aboue men quanto regia dignitas caeteras antecellit tanto caterarum gentium sentium regnorumque regni perfectio veſtri culmen excellit eſſe regem quia ſunt alij non mirum eſt sed eſſe catholicum quod alij non merentur hoc fortis eſt sicut enim magnae lampadis ſplendor tetrae noctis obſcuritate lumints ſui claritate fulgeſcit ita fidei veſtrae claritas inter aliarum gentium perfidiam rutilat atque place remarkeable letter tenure whereof thus enſueth letter written king clouis generall councell aſſembled orleans dominis ſanctis apoſtolica sede digniſsimis epiſcopis clodouaeus rex enunciante fama quid actum fuerit vel praeceptum omni exercitui nostro priuſquam patriam gothorum ingrederemur beatitudini veſtrae praeterire non potui primo quoque de miniſterio eccleſiarum omnium praecipimus ne ad ſubripiendum ea aliquis conaretur neque de sanctimonialib neque de viduis quae religione domini deuotae eſſe probantur▪ ſimili conditione de clericis vel filijs ſupradictorum tam clericorum quam viduarum qui cum illis domo ipſorum conſiſtere videbantur idem de ſeruis eccleſiarum quos de eccleſijs tractos per epiſcoporum ſacramenta conſtiterit praeceptum eſt obſeruare vt nullus ex ipſis aliquam violentiam vel damnum patiatur quod ita ad integrum eſt intelligendum vt ex ſupradictis ſi aliquis vim captiuitatis pertuliſſet ſiue eccleſia ſiue extra eccleſiam omnino ſine aliqua dilatione praecipiamus eſſe reddendos de ceteris quidem captiuis laïcis qui extra pacem ſunt captiuati fuerint approbati catholici aut cui volueritis arbitrij veſtri non eſt denegandum nam de qui pace noſtra tam clerici quam laïci ſubrepti fuerint ſi veraciter agnoſcitis veſtras epistolas de annullo veſtro infrà ſignat ſic ad no omnimodis dirigatis parte noſtra praeceptionem latam noueritis eſſe firmandum ſic tum populus noſter petit vt cuicumque epiſtolas veſtras praeſtare fueritis dignitati cum ſacramento per deum benedictione veſtra dicere non tardetis rem iſtam quae poſcitur veram eſſe quia multorum varietates falſitates inuentae ſunt vt comprehendantur ſicut ſcriptum eſt perit iuſtus cum impio orate pro domine ſancti apostolica sede papa digniſsimi ſecond placehis ſecōd purpoſe warre wherewith men woman cleanſe teeth vnſeemely faſhion yet common among people spaine like vnto thoſe indian malabar bathe waſh themſelues filthie muddie water therefore well may france tearmed kingdome kingdomes matthew paris engliſh hiſtorian ſaith anno etiam eodem verno tempore arridente inſurrexerunt multi magnate accincti ad praelium vt bellum mouerent aduerſus regnum galliae indignabantur enim
